episodes.content: Yokohama is home to Japan's biggest Chinatown. The neighborhood has survived war and disaster over the course of its long history. Now it's known as a culinary hotspot, attracting about 20 million visitors every year. But the coronavirus has ground business to a halt. This episode follows 3 people with deep roots to the area's storied dining industry, and looks at how they are overcoming the crisis. We also meet Vietnam-born Doan who is working to bring new development to Tokyo's Shibuya Ward.
episodes.description: The coronavirus pandemic is an unprecedented challenge for the restaurants of Yokohama's Chinatown. This episode focuses on the efforts of residents and business owners to overcome the crisis.
episodes.subtitle: Keeping the Faith in Chinatown
episodes.title: Where We Call Home

episodes.content: On this episode: a taste of sweetness with traditional confections, or "wagashi," prepared at a 200-year-old shop in Kumamoto City. Training under the 7th generation owner is his son-in-law, Mexican-born Saul Garcia Torres. Join us as we spend time with Saul on his journey toward becoming a master at preparing Japanese confections and creating new sugary sensations powered by his love of sweets and family. We also follow Amelia from the UK in her work to protect wild bears in Nagano Prefecture.
episodes.description: Join Mexican-born Saul Garcia Torres on his journey toward becoming a master of traditional Japanese sweets as he trains under his father in law, the 7th generation owner of a storied Kumamoto shop.
episodes.subtitle: For the Love of Sweets and Family
episodes.title: Where We Call Home

episodes.content: The former village of Oguchi in Ishikawa Prefecture was home to a 400-year-old wood weaving technique using Japanese cypress. Today, with the region's ongoing depopulation, the craft is threatened to disappear. We follow Australian Susan May who has been learning the technique under master artisan Katsuki Hisayo. Susan is attempting to weave a traditional woven hat for which the fabrication method has been lost. We also meet Bulgarian-native Ilko Allexandroff, a unique photographer living in Kobe.
episodes.description: We visit Ishikawa Prefecture to meet Australian Suzan May who's learning a local traditional wood weaving craft under a seasoned artisan. Master and apprentice are working hard to keep the art alive.
episodes.subtitle: Keeping Wood Weaving Alive
episodes.title: Where We Call Home

episodes.content: This episode takes us to the rural community of Kito in Tokushima Prefecture. While its population of around 1,000 is on the decline, a newcomer, Tyler Walkey from the US, is helping to breathe new life to the area. A talented video content creator, he uses his skills and a variety of methods from drones to time lapse shooting to promote the Kito region by filming its nature and its people. We also meet Chinese-born Chen Bowen who works at a store selling materials for making lacquerware.
episodes.description: This episode focuses on US-born Tyler Walkey, a talented video content creator who uses his skills and love of people to help revitalize the community of Kito in rural Tokushima Prefecture.
episodes.subtitle: Rural Reinvigoration on Video
episodes.title: Where We Call Home

episodes.content: On this episode, we meet Nigerian-native Chris Andrews, who runs a small shop in Saitama Prefecture's Koshigaya City. Open 365 days a year, Chris's business is a gathering spot and a source of moral support for the local Nigerian community. However, with the coronavirus pandemic, he struggles to keep his shop afloat. Join us as we follow Chris and the people who have come to his aid in his fight for survival. We also visit Bangladeshi Rashel Sarkar, who makes prosthetic legs at a company in Osaka Prefecture.
episodes.description: We visit the city of Koshigaya in Saitama Pref, to meet Nigerian-native Chris Andrews, who runs a small shop that's a gathering spot and a source of moral support for the local Nigerian community.
episodes.subtitle: Chris's Little Nigerian Shop
episodes.title: Where We Call Home

episodes.content: On this episode, we visit American-born Janie Ikegami who grows apples in Nagano Prefecture. Wishing to recreate the taste she loved growing up in her Texas home, Janie also began using her apples to make sauce and butter, which were unfamiliar to Japanese at first, but are now a huge hit. Yet Janie doesn't stop there; she's ready to take on a tasty new challenge. Join us to find out more. Later on, we drop by another Nagano location: a storied hotel where Russian-native Lyubov Zaozerova works.
episodes.description: We visit Nagano to meet US-born Janie Ikegami who uses the apples she grows to make applesauce and butter - two all - American delights that were new to Japan but are now a huge hit.
episodes.subtitle: American Taste, Japanese Apples
episodes.title: Where We Call Home
